title: Journalists (And Others) Should Leave Twitter. Here’s How They Can Get Started

last_post.content:
More and more public media companies "pause" posting on Saudi-government-funded Twitter.

Now is the time for some smart philanthropist to fund an entity that helps journalists set up shop on decentralized, open-source platforms (like Mastodon).

Help media orgs a) understand the value, which includes retaining control over what they create; b) bring their audiences along; and c) do the right thing.

I made some specific suggestions early this year: https://www.techdirt.com/2023/01/04/journalists-and-others-should-leave-twitter-heres-how-they-can-get-started/

title: Auditing Elon Musk's Impact on Hate Speech and Bots

last_post.content:
New paper on auditing Elon's early impact on Twitter.
- Hateful users became more hateful
- Hate increased dramatically
- There was no overall change in bots

Paper (accepted to ICWSM 2023) is here:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04129

title: https://imaging-neuroscience.org

last_post.content:
We're tootin' mad and we're not gonna take it anymore! Never imagined this would be my first post on Mastodon:

The entire editorial team at #NeuroImage, including myself, resigned today after #Elsevier refused to negotiate on their absurdly high publishing fees.

Are you *IN* with us? Authors, reviewers, and readers – please follow us to #ImagingNeuroscience!
https://imaging-neuroscience.org

title: The EU's Proposed CRA Law May Have Unintended Consequences for the Python Ecosystem

last_post.content: Another warning from #OpenSource foundations that the EU Cyber Resilience Act and Product Liability Act could have profound consequences on #FOSS communities - more folks should be more aware of this conversation. https://pyfound.blogspot.com/2023/04/the-eus-proposed-cra-law-may-have.html

title: https://w.wiki/W

last_post.content:
Hello Fediverse! 👋

#Wikipedia :wikipedia: is a multilingual free online encyclopedia written and maintained by a community of volunteers, known as Wikipedians, through open collaboration and using a wiki-based editing system called MediaWiki. -- or so says our Wikipedia article (https://w.wiki/W).

Follow for cool facts, behind-the-scenes details on editing processes and tips on getting started contributing!

#Introduction #FreeCulture #FreeContent #OpenKnowledge #wiki #CreativeCommons

NPR should get off Twitter. The New York Times should get off Twitter. The Washington Post, CBS, CNN, The Los Angeles Times should get off Twitter. Every journalist should get off Twitter.

You’re putting your product in the hands of a petty tyrant. I’m losing faith in your judgment.

Why is this hard?

https://www.npr.org/2023/04/05/1168158549/twitter-npr-state-affiliated-media

title: @Wikipedia - Meta

last_post.content:
Wikipedia is now on Mastodon, at @wikipedia!

They've taken an interesting approach here, as it is an account run by the community, where everyone can contribute (explanation here: https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/@Wikipedia). At the same time, it is verified on the official homepage of wikipedia.org, as you can see in the screenshot.

Personally, I think this suits the spirit of the fediverse that the Wikipedia account is not a PR department, but community members building something together!

title: I declined to share my medical data with advertisers at my doctor’s office. One company claimed otherwise

last_post.content: The problem with "opting out" of data tracking is that your requests can be ignored. Alex Rosenblat traced what happened to her medical opt-out requests when she was pregnant. What she found was that privilege vigilance isn't enough. https://www.statnews.com/2023/04/07/medical-data-privacy-phreesia/

First #RaspberryPi earned a shitstorm by hiring an ex-cop specialized in hidden surveillance.

title: What was selling out? - Anil Dash

last_post.content: Back in the late 20th century, a lot of folks used to worry about "selling out". I thought that people who don't remember that era well might find it useful to have a refresher on the concept, as well as a look at how it's been reinvented (and... improved?) in a modern context. https://www.anildash.com/2023/03/14/what-was-selling-out/

#Fedimeister is a #Java based #Mastodon client (available for #Linux, #Windows and #MacOS under the Apache #opensource license) with a focus on #writing and #journalism. Features:

* Break long texts into threads
* Scheduled posting
* Hashtag research
* #Twitter quote tweeting emulation

title: Science is a strong-link problem

last_post.content:
The most interesting critique of #PeerReview I've read in a long time is by @a_m_mastroianni.
https://www.experimental-history.com/p/science-is-a-strong-link-problem

The gist: We treat science as a weak-link problem (in which we fear opening the gates to the worst stuff) when when it's properly a strong-link problem (in which we should fear closing the gates to the best stuff).

h/t @DailyNous, who applied Mastroianni's thesis to #philosophy.
https://dailynous.com/2023/04/17/whats-so-bad-about-bad-philosophy/

#Academia, #AcademicMastodon
@academicchatter

title: Making a snappy raster map with shaders | Stamen

last_post.content: New blog post by Stamen's Lead Geospatial Developer Damon Burgett: "Making a snappy raster map with shaders". We go behind the scenes of our recent project with the Exploratorium, where we pushed the limits of visualizing raster map data with custom #MapboxGL shader layers. And as a bonus: Damon created a super-responsive #SeaLevelRise simulator to illustrate the concept. Read more and play with the sea level visualizer here: https://stamen.com/making-a-snappy-raster-map-with-shaders/ #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #GlobalWarming

last_post.content: Wonderful article about @internetarchive and how the lawsuit is bad news for book lovers and especially those in Yakutsk, the coldest inhabited city in the world. https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/the-internet-archives-troubles-are-bad-news-for-book-lovers/ ht @brewsterkahle

title: Tax Filing Websites Have Been Sending Users’ Financial Information to Facebook – The Markup

last_post.content:
H&R Block’s e-filing service attracts millions of customers per year.

We found code on its site gathering taxpayers’ sensitive financial information and sending it to Facebook.

That’s no longer happening thanks to our reporting: https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/11/22/tax-filing-websites-have-been-sending-users-financial-information-to-facebook

title: Creative Coding 2023

last_post.content: If you're in or even vaguely around Philly in June, there are still spaces available in my Creative Coding class at the Penn Dream Lab. No coding experience required. In fact, no experience is preferred! I've taught this course several years now and it's always a delight to introduce computational creativity to grad students, faculty, librarians, and alt-ac folks. https://web.sas.upenn.edu/dream-lab/creative-coding-2023/

title: Align your Latents: High-Resolution Video Synthesis with Latent Diffusion Models

last_post.content:
Align your Latents: High-Resolution Video Synthesis with Latent Diffusion Models

proj: https://research.nvidia.com/labs/toronto-ai/VideoLDM/
abs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08818

title: The Videogame Industry Does Not Exist: Why We Should Think Beyond Commercial Game Production

last_post.content:
The Videogame Industry Does Not Exist, my new book with @themitpress is out now! This is my attempt to intervene in how we talk and think about gamemaking as not just an entertainment industry but as a cultural field, built up from complex tensions between commercial and creative pressures and identities.

It's open access, and you can read it here: https://direct.mit.edu/books/oa-monograph/5572/The-Videogame-Industry-Does-Not-ExistWhy-We-Should

I wrote a long thread on Twitter with a bunch of excerpts which I won't reproduce here, but it's there if you're interested: https://twitter.com/BRKeogh/status/1648452116749643778

#gamestudies #mediastudies #culturalindustries #culturalproduction #commodon #gamedev

Having an amazing time at #PyConDE so far ✨🐍

For those of you who missed it or didn't get in because the room was full (sorry!!), here are the slides for my talk on incorporating LLMs into practical NLP workflows: https://speakerdeck.com/inesmontani/incorporating-llms-into-practical-nlp-workflows

title: Jeffrey Yasskin (@jyasskin@hachyderm.io)

last_post.content:
1. Without committing to any firm position, this is why “they’re just word prediction machines” is such a weak criticism of LLMs. There are things you can say about them that are both meaner and less reductive, so why turn to that one? But hey, I’m just a next-action machine, I guess.

2. More essays like this, I say. There are a lot of things I disagree with in it, but I never felt that my attention or the complexity of the issue was disrespected.

https://hachyderm.io/@jyasskin/110214994401056240

title: dailynous.com/2023/04/17/whats...

last_post.content:
The most interesting critique of #PeerReview I've read in a long time is by @a_m_mastroianni.
https://www.experimental-history.com/p/science-is-a-strong-link-problem

The gist: We treat science as a weak-link problem (in which we fear opening the gates to the worst stuff) when when it's properly a strong-link problem (in which we should fear closing the gates to the best stuff).

h/t @DailyNous, who applied Mastroianni's thesis to #philosophy.
https://dailynous.com/2023/04/17/whats-so-bad-about-bad-philosophy/

#Academia, #AcademicMastodon
@academicchatter

title: Triple Threat: NSO Group’s Pegasus Spyware Returns in 2022 with a Trio of iOS 15 and iOS 16 Zero-Click Exploit Chains - The Citizen Lab

last_post.content:
NEW INVESTIGATION: recent Mexican #Pegasus spyware abuses led us to evidence of a trio of zero-click exploits used by #NSO.

The #spyware victims: lawyers representing families of people forcibly disappeared by #Mexico's army.

The exploit targets we ultimately uncovered? #HomeKit & FindMy.

The HomeKit exploit worked even if the target had never added a home...

Remarkably, #Apple's #iOS #LockdownMode blocked one of them.

https://citizenlab.ca/2023/04/nso-groups-pegasus-spyware-returns-in-2022/

title: https://thi.ng/timestep

last_post.content:
Pragmatist that I am, I've been spending a lot of time over the past 24h to abstract & extract the fixed timestep/lockstep simulation update logic so that I (or others) don't need to re-implement the boilerplate for this type of update cycle for each new project. So a new (small) package is born:

https://thi.ng/timestep

Aside from the main update logic which entirely separates simulation state (and its update/integration) from rendering state (which will be derived/interpolated), the package also provides convenience wrappers for numeric or vector-based state variables. These are very useful, since the update logic requires 3 distinct versions of each sim state var: previous, current (next) and its interpolated version. Only the latter should be used outside the simulation (e.g. for rendering). It's all explained in the readme and the classic article by Glenn Fiedler (from 2004) upon which the core logic is based on...

In related news, I've also uploaded an updated version of #Bubblemania which is fully deterministic now (pixel perfection verified several times via difference images exported after 1000 and 2000 frames). Obviously I cannot update the version on fx(hash), but you can just copy your hash & params query string and append it as I've done here:

https://demo.thi.ng/umbrella/bubblemania/?fxhash=ooFcsnZBR21MRPkZeBMJFya6SZTtvnfoUzYpejfg5txRCCWnVyH&fxminter=tz1W2E9rSnHDftdygWiRjgVZzbw5y8oMN2z3&fxparams=01043ff000000000000000000000000000003fe3333333333333

#ThingUmbrella #GenerativeArt #Simulation #Determinism #TypeScript
